page.title: 13DURHAM CATHEDRAL
page.content: The{Cathedral}is one of the two most prominent landmarks of Durham,a sandstone tribute to{Norman {Architecture.}The Cathedral's purpose was to house the remains of the Saxon St.Cuthbert,who died on Lindisfarne in 687 AD.In 999 a church was consecrated on a peninsular of the River Wear which came to be known as Durham. Here Monks had fled with the body to escape marauding Danes.After the Norman Conquest,in order to put the Norman stamp on Durham the Normans started a new church.Its constrution took from 1093 to 1104 when the Saint's body was translated,undecayed. The main central tower is at present 218 feet high and the two western towers,whose original spires have been removed,are not so high.Inside the main features are the enormous pillars stretching the whole length of the
